title: Thursday, 25th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hi. Good morning, welcome to Thursday.

BE11:04am

So instead, let me tell you about my morning.

BE11:04am

A word postcard, if you will.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

8am or thereabouts. I jump on the bus. Number 18 down Harrow Road, full of school kids as usual.

BE11:05am

And the driver says, "hey there stranger. Have you heard about Gemalto?"

BE11:05am

I sighed, and said I'd heard quite a few rumours over the past few months. Nothing firm.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Traffic's slow. After a time I get off near Baker Street and nip into Starbucks. Medium black Americano to go.

BE11:05am

The barista says, "what's your name please and what do you know about this theory that Atos is bidding for Gemalto?"

BE11:05am

I said I'd heard the story going around, and had checked it out with people well positioned to know things.

11:05 am
BE11:06am

The impression given, repeatedly and forcefully, was that we probably should not believe it, I said.

BE11:06am

So anyway, I get my coffee and head down to the Jubilee Line southbound.

BE11:06am

Some American tourists are sitting opposite, mid 50s, excited to be somewhere new. Eastpak bags, comfortable slacks, sturdy walking shoes, you know.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

One asks me, "buddy, is this the train to St Pauls and also have you heard the rumour that Atos is wrapping up due diligence on an offer for Gemalto in the ballpark of €69 a share, advised by HSBC and Rothschild, with Atos advised by Lazard?"

BE11:07am

I said that, yes, rumours to that effect had reached us in recent days.

BE11:07am

But I emphasised that, as recently as very recently, we'd been steered with a firm hand away from pursuing them.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

It might be that people are being disingenuous to us, I said. French companies in particular have an unfortunate record when it comes to maintaining an honest market in the face of widespread rumourtrage. But then, market gossips aren't exemplary square shooters either, I added.

BE11:08am

So I apologised, said I can't say much beyond caveat emptor and change at Oxford Street for the red line eastbound to St Paul's.

BE11:08am

Then I cross through the market and beep into the office.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

... where Frank on reception says: "Good morning Bruce! Lovely weather we're having. What are the chances these Gemalto rumours are on the money?"

BE11:09am

I guess anything's possible, I replied: we've been steered wrongly before and will be again.

BE11:09am

All we can observe right now is that bum steers burn bridges, I said. And that works on both sides of a rumour.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

After emphasising that I was now strictly hypothetically, I continued: it would surely be a regulatory problem if a story spreads so far that a bus driver, a barista, a security guard and some tourists on the Tube are all hearing it, and then it turned out to be true.

BE11:09am

(It would also be a problem for the people who failed abjectly to keep secret price-sensitive information and created a false market, then kept the deal alive because they wanted the fees. That, however, is entirely hypothetical, I emphasised, now speaking in brackets.)

BE11:10am

Then I agreed with Frank that it was a lovely day, reminded him for the 26th time that my name's Bryce not Bruce, and went to the desk from where I'm typing now.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

It was a nice morning, all things considered. Welcome to Markets Live. FT Alphaville's daily whatever.

BE11:10am

Thanks for watching. We'll try to add value wherever we can.

undefined
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Wider market then! FTSE struggling to break above its record high.

BE11:11am

The psychologically important 7,522 level.

BE11:12am

Below the surface, kinda mixed. Lots of results, as usual for a Thursday.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Standout faller early doors is Petrofac, of course.

Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 433.10, down 181.9 (-29.58%), High: 557.50, Low: 404.00, Volume: 9.30m
BE11:13am

SFO update re the Unaoil scandal.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(Should I put "alleged" in there? No, I think "scandal" is okay. Too late now anyway.)

BE11:14am

News today is COO suspended until further notice.

BE11:14am

And has resigned as a consequence.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Which is bad! I mean, it's bad irrespective of the alleged bribery stuff.

BE11:15am

Because Petrofac needs to load on a lot of contracts to have any hope of making its guidance, and now it has to do it without its COO.

BE11:15am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

We believe the market will take this negatively, as the COO has been at the company since 1992 and we consider him a fundamental component of the E&C franchise. We are concerned that his departure may have a knock-on effect on Petrofac's operational oversight and ability to secure new work.

BE11:16am

Management changes due to the investigation were a risk, but one we did not expect to materialise so quickly. We reiterate our Underweight rating and expect this issue to continue to overhang the stock, leading to underperformance.

BE11:17am

And Numis.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

The language seems to be an escalation in a negative direction – with the phrase ‘given the scale of the investigation..’ not pointing towards this being resolved anytime soon. Also, and again with only negative implications as far as we can see, the board has suspended COO Marwan Chedid; Marwan came with CEO Ayman Asfari in 1992 to Petrofac and has been central (with Ayman) to the company’s success for 25 years.

BE11:17am

The SFO language certainly is an escalation!

BE11:18am

SFO says it "does not consider [Petrofac] to have cooperated with [its investigation], as that term is used in relevant SFO and sentencing guidelines."

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Beyond that, there's not much more to observe.

BE11:20am

It's bad that SFO's not accepting the findings of Petrofac's 2016 investigation.

BE11:21am

It's extremely bad that the CEO and COO were arrested and questioned under caution. (Did we know previously that they were arrested?)

11:21 am
BE11:21am

And clearly, the escalation has a readthrough for Amec and Wood Group.

BE11:21am

As yesterday's merger circular revealed that AMEC has been asked to prove information to the SFO regarding dealings with Unaoil

BE11:22am

And also that Wood Group JV also had historic dealings with Unaoil.

11:22 am
Amec Foster Wheeler PLC (AMFW:LSE): Last: 511.00, down 23 (-4.31%), High: 526.00, Low: 509.50, Volume: 1.65m
John Wood Group PLC (WG.:LSE): Last: 726.00, down 20.5 (-2.75%), High: 736.50, Low: 718.50, Volume: 1.73m
BE11:23am

Quick line from Numis.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

It represents a previously not widely known threat to the planned merger, and for those taking a view that the merger will not complete as a consequence, the obvious trade is short AMEC (which will likely have to immediately reboot its previously planned £500m rights issue, or find something other way to strengthen its over-levered balance sheet), long WG.

BE11:24am

Prospectus here if you want a read: https://www.woodgr...ed-23-May-2017.pdf

BE11:24am

And another quick line from Morgan Stanley.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Wood Group's ongoing internal investigation has so far "not concluded that payments made by Wood Group's joint venture to Unaoil were used in a way that amounted to bribery, corruption or money laundering". We find this reassuring. However, we note that in our experience, it is possible that internal investigations may not have the full range of materials that outside investigations by the authorities may have access to. For example, internal investigations by Saipem, SBM and Petrofac into their various compliance concerns did not preclude outside investigations

undefined
BE11:25am

Next!

11:26 am
BE11:26am

(Not Next. I mean, what's next? Confusing that. Sorry.)

BE11:27am

We'll get to Wizz Airways before midday, I guess. Though why we have so many people keen on a smallcap regional airline on the right has never been made entirely clear to me.

BE11:27am

There are a few larger things to note first though.

11:27 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 313.43, down 3.43 (-1.08%), High: 314.80, Low: 308.80, Volume: 14.25m
BE11:28am

Exane worrying about the divi. Downgrades to "underperform".

BE11:29am

Before going through the detail of that though, I note that BT went free to air last night for the European Football Thing.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Heavily promoted on Twitter, where feedback was .... well, mixed.

BE11:30am

Steel yourself and dive into the replies to this, for instance.

BE11:30am

https://twitter.com/btsport/status/864443959300554755

11:30 am
BE11:31am

50% of folk moaning about it only being in standard definition, not HD, and calling BT cheapskates

BE11:31am

25% of folk moaning that they paid for something that's being given away for free.

BE11:32am

25% of folk moaning that because of all the freeloaders the stream they may or may not have paid for didn't work.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Doing live sports is really difficult! And BT hasn't been doing it longer than a couple of years.

BE11:33am

One can ponder why shareholders want this noise rather than, for instance, dividend security.

BE11:33am

Which brings us back to Exane.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

BT’s shares have fallen ~40% from peak and investors are now asking “are we at the bottom?” Having been guilty of nudging down estimates bit by bit over the last 6 months, we thought it was time to take a step back and to challenge our long term forecasts and assumptions. The result? We can’t help feeling that the underlying business is teetering on the edge. We identify over a dozen factors (ex-regulation) that are underestimated by consensus and will place further pressure on EBITDA and FCF. In our view the market is mispricing BT as they transition from growth to decline.

BE11:04am

Had meant to find a picture to start, as is tradition, but it seems I ran out of time.

BE11:35am

Ofcom may have semi-reneged on the FTTC fair-bet with 40Mbps price cuts and BT may think that is unfair, but we see little scope for a change in view before the details are finalised (end ’17). Ofcom will not be happy until they see more investment. BT has launched a “fibre consultation” which will likely lead to more FTTP, but the UK is a poor place to build a national FTTP or G.fast network, so BT face structural upwards pressure on capex, just as consumer spend is plateauing.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

BT have already signalled their “progressive dividend growth” will be lower than the historical greater than 10%, but on our new estimates they face a GBP800m cash shortfall over 3 years to fund just 2% growth. This promise leaves them on the back foot; a constraint to competitive flexibility and ability to bid on crucial spectrum/content auctions. So does BT want to be a company that faces constant questions over dividend sustainability and one criticised for not investing enough in “full fibre”?

BE11:35am

When Mr du Plessis joins, we think he will find a company with deteriorating fundamentals struggling to balance the interests of all stakeholders. We encourage him to re-base the dividend to a more sustainable level: a 30% cut would bring the pay-out in closer to historic levels. Whilst an explicit long term capex plan would re-base expectations and ease regulatory pressure. Together these would put the BT on surer footing to deal with the multitude of challenges ahead.

BE11:36am

Imagine ... a BT 30% dividend cut.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

When the cost base currently looks like this.

BE11:38am

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:39am

Some strategy talk on the right.

BE11:39am

Which reminds me that Deutsche's pro UK this morning.

BE11:39am

FTSE's the cheapest major market in Europe, they say.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Avoid FTSE 250 due to the domestic stuff. Sterling weakness, Brexit, election, etc. But buy the 100.

BE11:40am

Here's the gist.

BE11:41am

We expect cyclicals to continue underperforming defensives over the coming months: European cyclicals have underperformed defensives by 5% over the past month. We expect this underperformance to continue, as Euro area PMIs roll over from their current elevated levels and Euro area macro surprises turn negative, both of which are associated with cyclical underperformance. The FTSE 100, as one of the most defensive major indexes in Europe, tends to outperform when cyclicals weaken relative to defensives.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Our FX strategists remain bearish on Sterling: they have recently reduced their projected downside for the currency, but still expect Sterling trade-weighted to weaken by year-end on the back of a deterioration in UK macro data. With 60% of FTSE 100 revenues coming from outside the UK, Sterling weakness tends to boost the UK’s relative performance.

BE11:41am

Downside for energy seems limited from here: Energy has been the weakest sector in Europe year-to-date, underperforming by 12%. This has weighed on the FTSE 100’s relative performance, as energy is the index’s largest sector overweight. Yet, with energy now cheap on both our sector fair-value model and relative P/Es, the energy-related drag on the FTSE 100 should be limited from here.

BE11:41am

Our FTSE 100 model points to around 5% relative upside until year-end, given DB macro forecasts and our projected underperformance of cyclicals vs defensives. Valuations further support the FTSE 100 overweight: the relative 12-month forward P/E is close to a 3-year low – and the UK ranks as the cheapest market on our European country valuation scorecard.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Underweight FTSE 250 versus FTSE 100: the FTSE 250 has outperformed the FTSE 100 by 5% since the beginning of the year, as UK PMIs have shown unexpected strength. Yet, PMIs are now consistent with UK GDP growth at 2.5% in 2017, significantly above our economists’ forecast of 1.6%. If PMIs fade back to the levels consistent with our economists’ forecasts, this would imply around 5% downside for the FTSE 250 relative to the FTSE 100 from current levels. Sterling weakness and bouts of political uncertainty around the election and the UK’s Brexit negotiations could add to this downside.

BE11:42am

Similar stuff in recent days from Barclays, if I remember correctly.

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:44am

Sorry, distracted for a moment. Let's kick on.

BE11:44am

And to results. There's Pets At Home.

BE11:46am

...... which is refusing to autoprice. Up 2.8% at pixel anyway.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

On what are pretty awful figures.

BE11:48am

And the (expected) warning that they're going to sacrifice price for volume.

BE11:48am

And the (expected) warning that they're going to sacrifice price for volume.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

This is in effect a veiled profit warning, but one that seems factored in by the share price slump in recent months

BE11:49am

Which was helped along by good work from the likes of Geoff Ruddell at Morgan Stanley, who highlighted the margin issue.

BE11:49am

Here's his response to today's update.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

- Although the results for FY 2016/17 here are broadly in line, the focus today will be on the guidance for FY 207/18 which is likely to lead to consensus forecasts falling 10-15% today.
- Results for FY 2016/17 appear pretty routine. Pre Tax Profits have come in at £96.4m (vs consensus of £96.2m). Trading in the fourth quarter appears to have picked up slightly (Merchandise LfL up 0.5%), but it is hard compare the FY Q4 figures against our forecasts as the company has reported an Easter-adjusted, rather than actual, LfL.

BE11:50am

- The focus today, though, is likely to be on the guidance for FY 2017/18. A couple of weeks ago we published a report in which we predicted that Pets at Home would invest a couple of hundred basis points over the next three years in gross margins. Today the company has guided gross margins down 100-200bps in FY 2017/18, as well as forecast cost growth of 4.5%-5.5%. This is likely to result in material cuts to consensus forecasts today.

BE11:51am

(Spin back in the archive for a summary of that "category killer" note. It's good.)

11:51 am
BE11:51am

- Although it will get less publicity today, we think it is also worth noting that the group is also guiding to just 10 new store openings this year (vs 15 last year).
- Having spoken with the company this morning, we envisage consensus Pre Tax Profit forecasts for FY 2017/18 falling to around £85m. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for Pre Tax Profits of £97m (we cut to £87m two weeks ago).
- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Pets at Home is trading on 10.5x Calendar 2017 earnings, 7.1x EBITDA with a 4.8% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 13.9x, 8.3x and 3.8% respectively.

BE11:52am

And Citi.

BE11:52am

Implications — March 2018E PBT consensus likely down c.15%— With gross margin guidance -100-200bps, opex growth 4.5-5.5% we expect consensus to decline c.15%. Consensus currently estimates c. £95m for FY18 PBT. We currently forecast PBT of £98m.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

We are Buyers given the growth opportunity in Services, and the company’s current cash generation (FCF margin 10%). We also believe that the market is factoring in too much downside risk to the merchandise business. Over the next 10 years we believe that the vet business could generate an incremental £40m of EBITDA on a FY16 Group EBITDA base of £125m and account for over 35% of total group EBITDA (vs est c.18% currently). However, we appreciate that in order for the merchandise business to re-rate there will need to greater comfort for investors that online competition can be addressed successfully.

BE11:53am

Note by the way that it's 10 new shops for the current year but 40-50 vet practices and 40-50 groom rooms.

BE11:54am

I know I've waffled about this in the past, but vets practices are really difficult to run.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Approximately 100% of your customers die very seven years.

BE11:55am

And the consolidation model is tricky. Shared services etc only really work in highly urbanised areas.

BE11:57am

Where there are deeply embedded competitors. Mostly family owned single operator practices, which Pets can try to buy out or try to close down.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

It's a very high risk expansion strategy, needing very careful management. And I'm yet to be convinced that Pets, so recently in PE ownership, has the chops to do it flawlessly.

undefined
BE11:58am

Sorry, that waffle about vets took rather longer than I planned.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

What else? Wizz was promised, so ......

BE11:59am

FY profit (ignoring the noise) misses consensus by a fraction. Guidance is reassuring tho.

Wizz Air Holdings PLC (WIZZ:LSE): Last: 2,143, up 197 (+10.12%), High: 2,170, Low: 2,007, Volume: 974.53k
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Barclays, I think, has seen enough to turn positive.

BE12:00pm

Y17 RESULTS: SUMMER VINDICATION. We upgrade Wizz Air to OW following the company’s FY17 results release today. Q4 17 net profit of -€20m was at the low end of Wizz’s guidance range, but the initial outlook for FY18 and peak summer trading is very encouraging, with underlying pricing improving to flattish despite Wizz ramping up its own growth rate to 23%. The company’s FY18 net profit guide of €250-€270m is ~10% above consensus, and our EPS forecasts in FY18 FY19 rise by 18% 15% respectively. The summer outlook vindicates management’s choice to focus on growth. Whether margins can quite get back to 15% remains to be seen, but on fundamentals this is a high quality business with clear long-term structural growth trajectory at an attractive valuation. On 10.5x 12m fwd P/E, it trades at a 20% discount to Ryanair / 30% discount to easyJet.

BE12:01pm

And Panmure.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Initial FY18 guidance for net profit of €250m-€270m suggests c.10% upside to €234m consensus at the mid-point. Wizz has enjoyed a strong start to the year, helped by Easter, and sees no signs of demand weakness on routes to/from the UK post-referendum. Capacity is expected to grow by 23% in FY18, higher than PGe 17%, as Wizz capitalises on growth opportunities in the market. RASK has been guided to a low single increase in FY18, which is much strong than our -3% forecasts, and we think consensus expectations, with more stable fuel prices and industry capacity edging back creating a more benign pricing environment. Whilst we expect the market to apply a degree of caution given the low visibility over peak summer yields at this early stage, the incrementally positive tone on yields should be taken well by investors. Ex-fuel unit costs are guided flat with fuel CASK +10%.

BE12:02pm

Investment case. Wizz Air has the raw ingredients and market conditions to take its successful proposition to a whole new scale. Low cost DNA enables Wizz to charge low fares profitably, with structural growth coming from robust core market economies and increasing propensity to fly, positive migration trends and low LCC penetration. With a comparable and sustainable cost base to the market leader, Ryanair, and strong margins and ROIC, Wizz has the right model for the CEE region and to capitalise on weak legacy carriers. We believe any near-term (self-inflicted) pain from aggressive capacity/share growth should be viewed as a natural corollary to taking advantage of medium-term structural opportunities; in our view the main driver of shareholder value.

undefined
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Midday summaries from the merger arbs are dropping through ....

BE12:03pm

GEMALTO (GTO NA) - FT Alphaville comments on recent Atos bid speculation...

BE12:04pm

Yes -- I think that's a reasonable way to summarise what happened. Anything else would test the reader's patience.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

ROTR, meanwhile, have disappeared off into DPL for reasons that have evaded me.

BE12:07pm

.......... and vol. (@bones: in my experience, if the explanation sounds like a conspiracy theory it usually is.)

BE12:08pm

We, however, should probably round up.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Haven't mentioned Acacia, which is having a day-two slump.

Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 268.60, down 36.4 (-11.93%), High: 311.00, Low: 261.20, Volume: 2.68m
BE12:09pm

... which can be summarised by BMO.

12:08 pm
BE12:09pm

Bottom Line: A committee of academics and industry professionals stated that the value of minerals within inspected containers was more than ten times the amount declared by Acacia. A discrepancy of such magnitude appears difficult to reconcile given that it would represent anomalous performance for well-established operations, indicate a significant failure of regulated export processes, and require collaboration from numerous entities. Regardless, it now appears that a near-term resolution to resume concentrate exports may be difficult to achieve, likely forcing management to consider the suspension or curtailment of operations.

BE12:10pm

And RBC too, if you like.

BE12:10pm

Government claims Acacia under-reporting contained gold in concentrate. Within the context of the ongoing dispute between Acacia and the Tanzanian government, the Presidential audit has stated that mining concentrates and specifically certain concentrates from Acacia Mining that were at the port at the time of the launch of the commission had been under-reported with regards to the contained gold for export by a factor of 10. In our view, this accusation is highly unusual (and metallurgically questionable) and therefore further investigations may (in theory) provide some relief for the company although it is unclear what next steps can be taken to clarify this matter. Regardless, according to press reports (e.g., Reuters), the President has called for the authorities to investigate, he has fired the mining minister and has dissolved the audit committee. We see this placing the company's license to operate under pressure. With the lack of near-term resolution to the concentrate ban and uncertainty around the future implications, we see investors further discounting the potential cash flows in the near and medium term.

Export ban remains in place - uncertainty of sustainability of Bulyanhulu and Buzwagi. With the uncertainty around near-term viability of the concentrate production at Bulyanhulu and Buzwagi, we would expect Acacia will consider temporarily halting these operations to avoid a further build-up of working capital from the concentrate which it is unable to sell. Without a clear path to resolution, cash flows, as well as any spending on North Mara are both likely to fall, which further erodes near-term potential. At this point, we leave our forecasts unchanged, but will revisit once further clarity on operational strategy is disclosed.

Management will continue to engage with the authorities and a resolution is still possible, setting up a value opportunity. It is possible that Acacia could be cleared by any independent investigation, although we think international litigation looks increasingly likely. The economic consequences to Tanzania of shutting down what would be otherwise viable mining operations, especially with the negative mark that this could place on foreign direct investment, could see an eventual resolution arise (a government stake? Higher taxes?). We expect management will continue to engage and do their utmost to protect shareholder value. In the meantime, with such heightened uncertainty, we reduce our target multiple for Tanzanian exposure within Acacia to 0.6x NAV. Adding in the cash and value for Kenya at 1.0x NAV, we reduce our target price to 315p and downgrade our rating to Underperform.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

We value Acacia on a blend of 0.6x P/NPV for the Tanzanian assets and 1.0x P/NPV for the Kenyan assets as well as 8x P/CF, a discount to peers for a variety of risks including uncertainty around the presidential audit, single-country exposure, a lack of liquidity, and the overhang from the Barrick Gold stake. This generates a 315p price target, which supports our Underperform rating.

BE12:11pm

There's also a bit of slotting to note. OneSavings ... FeverTree ....

OneSavings Bank PLC (OSB:LSE): Last: 435.30, down 32.2 (-6.89%), High: 440.00, Low: 433.70, Volume: 26.58m
12:11 pm
Fevertree Drinks PLC (FEVR:LSE): Last: 1,672, down 76.5 (-4.38%), High: 1,708, Low: 1,656, Volume: 9.83m
BE12:12pm

Fever-Tree one's particularly precious.

BE12:12pm

Fever-Tree announces that, due to significant institutional demand, the Selling Shareholder has, subject to completion, sold 4,500,000 ordinary shares in the Company ......

12:12 pm
BE12:12pm

Due to significant institutional demand I've decided to slot £73m.

BE12:14pm

I didn't want the £73m! Heaven forfend! But institutions demanded I take it, in exchange for less than 4% of for a soda maker that trades somewhere not too shy of 100x earnings.

BE12:14pm

W'evs.

12:14 pm
BE12:14pm

Anyway, we're done. Thanks for joining.

BE12:14pm

See you tomorrow.

BE11:34am

(@Vixal: nah, old style smokebelching double decker.)
